name: Diana Ross
religion: Ross is a borderline devout Baptist Christian.
politicalViews: Ross is a Democrat and major pioneer for African Americans.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Diana Ross was born and raised in Detroit, Michigan.
Ross was raised a Baptist and sang in the church choir in her hometown of Detroit.
Interviews with Ross are rare and coveted among media folk.
content.sourceTitle: A rare interview with singer Diana Ross

content.text: Thus, there isn't much to go on for those hoping to get a clear picture of her spiritual/religious mentality. In her 2008 autobiography, Ross mentioned God a few times, indicating that she is still at least somewhat devout. For example:
Learning to let go and let God [take over] has been a tremendous lesson for me.
content.sourceTitle: Diana Ross Memoirs: Secrets of a Sparrow

content.text: Furthermore, Ross credited God to her fame and success in the dog-eat-dog boys club of the mid-20th Century Motown music scene.
content.sourceTitle: Diana Ross Memoirs: Secrets of a Sparrow

content.text: There are some rumors that Ross converted to Judaism. This isn't true as far as I can tell, though she was briefly married to a Jewish businessman, Robert Silberstein.
content.sourceTitle: Beautiful People and Gleeful Broadway St

content.text: That leaves us to conclude that Ross is perhaps a borderline devout Baptist today.
Race pioneering since back in the day
Ross has been a staple in the Democratic Party for nearly 50 years, ever since she and The Supremes sang at campaign events for Lyndon Johnson in the mid-60s.
Since then, she has sung for numerous Democratic presidents including the Clintons
and the Obamas.
content.sourceTitle: Michelle Obama Gets Bejeweled With Diana Ross For 'Christmas In Washington.'

content.text: But celebrity transcends partisan politics, and though Ross didn't sing for him, she did accept an award from President George W. Bush.

Ross' most significant political contributions were helping to shatter racism and usher in the Civil Rights movement. Her Motown trio, The Supremes, was among the first African American wave of musicians to cross over into the white music marketplace. This paved the way for broader acceptance of American black culture.
content.sourceTitle: Diana Ross on Racism and Civil Rights (late 1980's)

content.text: In 1968, Ross and the other two Supremes were specifically invited to Martin Luther King Jr's funeral
and for years afterwards, Ross would say King's immortalized words at her concerts:
Free at last. Free at last. Thank God almighty, free at last!
content.sourceTitle: Diana Ross on Racism and Civil Rights (late 1980's)

content.text: Even today, race is foremost on Ross' mind. In her 2008 autobiography, she wrote:
I have tried to open up opportunities for blacks, for women, for minorities. Every time I go into a project, my first thought is about hiring as many minorities as are capable of doing the work.
content.sourceTitle: Diana Ross Memoirs: Secrets of a Sparrow

content.text: She is widely considered instrumental in the advancement of African Americans in the last 50 years.
